questions.question: In what year was the Roman monarchy abolished and the Republic established?
How many consuls governed the Roman Republic at any given time?
What was the primary reason for creating two consuls instead of one?
options: To prevent the concentration of power
To reduce the cost of government
To facilitate trade with neighboring cities

questions.question: What is the term for a consul's right to block the decisions of his colleague?
After their one-year term as consul, what could happen to a consul who abused his power?
options: He could immediately run for another term
He was protected from any legal action
He could be prosecuted for his actions in office
He automatically became a senator for life
questions.text_reference: Section 1: The One-Year Term and Accountability

questions.question: Which assembly was responsible for electing consuls in the early Republic?
What was the primary role of the Roman Senate under the Republic?
options: To command Rome's armies during military campaigns and approve all military expeditions
To directly vote on and pass all major laws proposed by magistrates
To control state finances and direct foreign policy decisions
To investigate crimes, prosecute offenders, and administer justice to all citizens

questions.question: Which of the following was NOT a magistracy below the consulship in the early Republic?
What Latin term describes the unwritten customs and precedents that held the force of law in Rome?
What fundamental principle did the Republic establish that was NOT true under the kings?
options: No one, not even the highest magistrate, stood above the law
One single ruler held all governmental power and made decisions alone
The ruler was answerable only to the gods and no earthly authority
The ruler could serve for life and pass the throne to successors
